result_equations.equation: u(nu, T) = (8 pi h nu^3)/c^3 * 1/(exp(h nu/(k_B T)) - 1)

explanation: Blackbody radiation describes the electromagnetic radiation emitted by an ideal absorber (blackbody) in thermal equilibrium. The spectral energy density follows Planck's distribution, which resolved the ultraviolet catastrophe and led to quantum theory. This radiation depends only on temperature and is fundamental to thermodynamics, stellar physics, and quantum mechanics.

definitions.definition: Spectral energy density per unit frequency at temperature T.

assumptions.text: The body is an ideal absorber and emitter (perfect blackbody).
The system is in thermal equilibrium at temperature T.
Electromagnetic modes in the cavity are quantized with energy E = ℏω.
Electromagnetic field modes are independent oscillators.
Each mode is in thermal equilibrium described by canonical ensemble.

derivation.description: Calculate the density of electromagnetic modes in a cavity using wave mechanics.
derivation.equation: g(nu) = (8 pi nu^2)/c^3 (density of electromagnetic modes)

derivation.description: Apply Planck's quantum hypothesis: each mode has discrete energy levels.
derivation.equation: E_n = n h nu (quantized energy levels, n = 0, 1, 2, ...)

derivation.description: Calculate the average occupation number using Boltzmann statistics.
derivation.equation: <n> = sum_{n=0}^oo n exp(-n h nu/(k_B T))/sum_{n=0}^oo exp(-n h nu/(k_B T))

derivation.description: Evaluate the geometric series to get the Bose-Einstein distribution for photons.
Find the average energy per mode by multiplying occupation by quantum energy.
Multiply mode density by average energy to get spectral energy density.
derivation.equation: u(nu, T) = g(nu) <E> = (8 pi h nu^3)/c^3 * 1/(exp(h nu/(k_B T)) - 1)

derivation.description: Integrate over all frequencies to get total energy density (Stefan-Boltzmann law).
derivation.equation: U = int_0^oo u(nu, T) dnu = sigma T^4 (Stefan-Boltzmann law)

derivation.description: Evaluate the integral to determine the Stefan-Boltzmann constant.
